subject: mathematics
explanation: Direct proportion: as one quantity increases, the other increases at the same rate (y = kx). Inverse proportion: as one quantity increases, the other decreases (y = k/x). Examples: Direct - more workers, more work done. Inverse - more speed, less time taken. Look for constant ratios (direct) or constant products (inverse).

examples.question: If 4 apples cost £2, how much do 10 apples cost? (Direct proportion)
examples.explanation: Direct proportion: cost ÷ apples is constant. £2 ÷ 4 = £0.50 per apple. So 10 apples = 10 × £0.50 = £5

examples.question: If 6 workers take 8 days to complete a job, how long will 12 workers take? (Inverse proportion)
examples.explanation: Inverse proportion: workers × days is constant. 6 × 8 = 48. So 12 workers take 48 ÷ 12 = 4 days
